column6: Although no mention of toxicity has been seen for this species, it belongs to a genus that contains a number of plants with a cumulative poisonous effect on the liver[65]. Some caution is advised.
column8: Circumboreal. Formerly native to Britain, now apparently extinct[17].
column16: Tephroseris palustris is a ANNUAL/BIENNIAL growing to 0.6 m (2ft).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 4.  It is in flower from June to July, and the seeds ripen from July to August. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Bees, flies.  Suitable for: light (sandy) and medium (loamy) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  moist or  wet soil.
column21: Young leaves and flowering stems - raw or cooked[177, 257]. They have been eaten raw in salads, cooked as greens or have been fermented into a sauerkraut[257]. Some caution is advised, see the notes above on toxicity.
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.None known
column27: Requires a gritty, moisture-retentive but well-drained circumneutral soil and a sunny position[200]. Plants can be short-lived in cultivation[200].
column28: Seed - sow spring or late summer in situ. Only just cover the seed and make sure the soil remains moist to enable germination to take place.
